2825.70.text: I'd like to close with two observations.

2828.24.text:
One, a few remarks about a recent exhibition
in London,

2831.86.text:
it was last year I think at the Sultan of
Brunei's Gallery

2835.57.text: at SOAS [School of Oriental and African Studies].

2836.55.text:
It was called Empire, Faith and War and it
was curated by the British Sikh community.

2842.38.text:
They collected artefacts from families 
to do with

2844.54.text: the Sikh experience of the First World War,

2846.34.text: and I was asked to give a talk then.

2849.75.text:
And that's when Santanu came up with that
expression: 'Illiterate but literary'.

2854.62.text:
But one of the items they found was one of
the original letters.

2857.60.text:
It had been written by a teenage girl, 
they think,

2861.67.text: to her father serving at the front.

2865.58.text:
It was written in Gurmukhi, Punjabi written
in the script of the guru.

2870.88.text:
And, interestingly, in the letter she was
telling her father

2875.34.text: that she'd learnt to read and write.

2877.25.text:
She had done this in order that she could
read his letters out to her mother

2882.52.text:
instead of having to rely on 
a village letter reader.

2886.52.text:
So there was less risk of his letters home
becoming subject to village gossip.

2891.67.text:
I was very touched both by the idea 
in the letter

2895.44.text:
and by the fact that one of the originals
has been rediscovered.

2902.81.text:
I'd like to end with the dedication 
of the book

2905.70.text: which is, of course, to the Indian soldiers.

2908.17.text:
There was never any doubt as a Jersey man
in my mind what this dedication would be.

2913.47.text:
It was an extract of Norman French 
medieval poetry

2916.45.text:
written by Maistre Wace who, like me, 
was born in Jersey.

2921.71.text: To medieval scholars it's a very famous passage,

2924.73.text: and many people in Jersey know it, too.

2928.79.text:
I put it as a dedication and I deliberately
left it untranslated for several reasons.

2935.04.text:
First, of course, poetry is difficult to translate,
particularly if, like me,

2939.29.text:
your main languages are French, German and
Italian, not medieval Anglo-Norman French.

2945.13.text:
Secondly, I wanted it to stand out as the
only passage not in English

2949.72.text:
in a book in which virtually all the letters
are translations into English.

2955.46.text:
And thirdly, I wanted to weave a passage of
poetry into the book

2958.68.text:
in a language that many readers would not
immediately understand,

2962.53.text:
just as the Indian soldiers had woven poetry
into their letters to confuse the censors.

2967.89.text:
I'm not going to try to read it out in medieval
Norman French,

2970.83.text: but I will approximate a translation into English,

2975.40.text: only my translation is probably not very good.

2978.90.text:
It reads, 'Everything starts to decline, 
everything falls,

2982.40.text: everything dies, everything comes to an end.

2985.55.text:
Unless a scholar puts it in a book, 
it cannot last nor live.'
